replies.author: @probusexcogitatoris736
replies.text: @Obs23456 Well, the reason I used the term 'born' is because that is the overwhelmingly most prevalent form of patriotism. Of course you have exceptions where someone are patriotic towards a country they weren't born in because of ancestry or even a deep fascination and identification of a foreign culture. But, it's nonetheless about the individual and them being born in that country. Also, far from all patriots have a deep heritage. Especially in USA, most patriots are actually ancestors of immigrants not that many generations ago. Even second-generation immigrants are often patriots. They adopt the heritage of their nation as their own. Whether there is an actual bloodline is not the most important thing for most patriots. It's a sense of a shared common national heritage. Very few Americans are related to the founding fathers, but still patriots regard them as their national fathers. The very fact that the term 'father' is used to describe these people goes to show how national heritage is not the same as personal heritage through bloodlines.

author: @LvOneRose
text:
A point on the crusade; Thomas Asbridge claims that many people went in order to seek absolution for their sins. The reason why the warrior class in particular needed to cleanse their sins was because the Catholic Church condemned tournaments at the time of the first crusade.

Now, based more of my own memory of other sources, 1095 was a relatively peaceful time (especially compared to the other crusade times). This meant the warrior class had no way of demonstrating prowess and gaining renown outside of tournaments. A crusade, then, would have offered them the chance to gain said renown.

author: @fuzzydunlop7928
text: In regards to the pre-WW1 European fervor for war, I've always wondered if during that period the still-living memory of the US Civil War had something to do with how late the US entered the conflict, or if it significantly shaped perceptions of warfare in general in ways opposite Europeans of the day.

replies.author: @blahblahghost
replies.text:
Fuzzy Dunlop seems pretty sound. Americans could remember what "modern war" looked like. They knew it wasnt going to be like Napoleonic battles. All grandeur and "honor". They knew that what was supposed to be a quick conflict turned into a 4 year slog were 600,000 Americans had died, and especially in the south, they had experienced total war. 

You also have to remember that Americans were dealing with a belligerent Mexico at the time, and the thought of sending troops south was a big enough issue.

 Creating an American Expeditionary Force that would go all the way to Europe was not something most Americans wanted or even saw the point of, Even after the unrestricted sub warfare and the deaths of Americans on the Atlantic.

replies.author: @Durandurandal
replies.text: I do recall a strong sentiment of "isolationist" running through the country as well. It's "their war, somewhere else" sort of thing. A major plank of Wilson's reelection campaign was specifically not getting into the war, after all (didn't really hold true to that)

replies.author: @nakenmil
replies.text: Keep in mind that the US had a pretty cool relationship with European powers at the time as well, having had wars with the Spanish not too much earlier, and seeing European colonialism in the Americas as dangerous meddling.

replies.author: @nakenmil
replies.text:
It should also be mentioned that the Napoleonic Wars saw their own post-war reaction of horror, which is why we see the Concert of Europe and the Metternicht Plan, which attempted (and partly succeeded) in preventing another "continental war" for almost 100 years (although there were certainly a lot of other wars inbetween).

Interestingly, the Napoleonic Wars also contains some of the same points mentioned above, the idea that once the people get invested in the goal of the war personally, it suddenly becomes a whole lot harder to stop it in a sensible way. Keep in mind, that from the perspective of the French, the Napoleonic War was an extension of the Revolutionary Wars, it was about spreading the new rational rule across the world, and enlightenment values against the broken aristocratism of Germany, Russia and Britain. Those parts in turn saw France as a horrendous threat to their traditions, values, and way of life, much like the Western powers viewed the Soviet Union in the Cold War.

replies.author: @fuzzydunlop7928
replies.text:
+Enthused Norseman - that comparison of Revolutionary France and the Soviet Union seems very apt, but I don't see it get used very often, for some reason.

*Hunter deja - If I remember correctly, Roosevelt renounced his jingoism shortly before his death, mostly due to seeing the slaughter of the First World War. Could also be from public backlash, as you've stated.

replies.author: @fuzzydunlop7928
replies.text: "Wilson eventually was compelled to as Congress to declare war against Germany. In his defense what else could he do after Germany resumed unrestricted submarine warfare and after the Zimmerman Papers were found which tried to instigate Mexico to attack America." - He could do nothing, I don't think the public was whipped up into such a fervor that no-war was politically damming. Like you said, "He Kept Us Out of War" - nothing short of a "Pearl Harbor" is going to make that winning political slogan irrelevant during that time period. If anything, more people would've been more apt for harsher repercussions for Mexico. They are at lot closer and a lot more 'hated' and most importantly a lot weaker.

replies.author: @PhilipOCarroll
replies.text: No the US Civil war was as remote then as World War II is to us.

replies.author: @DG9-q6f
replies.text: blahblahghost - I would disagree over US Civil War giving a glimpse of a "modern war": the insufficient industrial capacities at the time spared the conflict from the worst of trench warfare. Also, most of the countries on the continent also had examples of wars that did not go as planned: Franco-Prussian, Anglo-Boer, and Russo-Japanese (even if these disasters were not as bloody as US Civil War).

replies.author: @SOMEGUY7893
replies.text: @Fuzzy Dunlop Had an American ship been sunk and he said we won't go to war in retaliation or any sort of retaliation really. People back then would've eaten him alive for letting something like that happen.

replies.author: @SOMEGUY7893
@Vberg
replies.text: If you look at the fervour that many Americans greeted the war it was suprising how similar the common Americans reaction to entering the war was to their European conterparts. This inspite of nearly three years of the first world war and as others have said Americas experiences in the Civil War. Due to the Zimmerman Telegram, Germanys resumption of unrestricted U-Boat warfare, German actions (both real and exagerated) in Belgium and German sponsored Sabotage on US soil made it politically impossible, with the likes of Theodore Roosevelt whipping up jingoistic sentiment, for Woodrow Wilson to keep the US out of the war. It was a turning point for the US and gave rise to the military industrial complex that is so central to US foreign power today. The very Idea of US taxpayers paying for the maintenance of large armed forces would have been unthinkable to the founding fathers. Prior to American entry into the war the US army was at most 200000 strong. Just two years later over 4 million Americans had served at one point or other in the armed forces. The sleeping giant had awoken.

author: @spacecadet9663
text: My great grandfather was a welshman that was targeted by the order of the white feather during the early years of the war. According to the story told to me by my grandfather before he passed on was that my great grandfather, Frederick, hadn't enlisted at least in part due to his ardent Welsh nationalist sympathies and didn't think it was just for the victims of English colonialism to enlist and die by the thousands in a war they had by and large been dragged kicking and screaming to. He was a fairly poor laborer working in the Welsh city of Swansea, and wished to dissuade several other groups of young working class men from joining the British war effort. These activities caught the attention of the order of the white feather, and earned him a visit from a group of them one night when he was walking to his tenant home near the harbor. They accosted him for being a "coward" and being unwilling to defend his homeland. He responded that Wales hadn't been "his" homeland since the time of Edward the third, and that even today the English crown send young men like himself to die in the pursuit of their own aims. He then asked them if it would be cowardly to defend his homeland against the much closer threat of English cultural imperialism, at which point the women pinned the white feather into his hat and walked away in disgust. I bring this up because I feel that a lot of people tend to forget that this is still the case for celtic ethnic groups in the UK. Britons, Picts, Scots, and the Welsh might have some level of freedoms assigned to each but that doesn't change the fact that for many of these groups there has been a long history of state sanctioned violence and repression on the part of the English against them. Still to this very day, Wales and northern Ireland do not have home rule even though the Brits decided to give such privileges to the Scottish. And while these areas have managed to hold onto a separate identity independent of English or British identity, that came at the expense of Welsh and Scots standing up against a systemic attempt to rid the world of celtic identity, history, as well as even our own goddamned names. I was shocked to find out that my quaint English sounding last name carried a much longer lineage with it than I ever really thought.

author: @bikerusl
text:
Wow, Thank you for making this. It is incredibly inciteful. In the English speaking world our history from this time is, necessarily, US/UK perspective. Our historians do not emphasize the role of UK propaganda so clearly. Frankly, I was taught that most of the stories about Belgium, were British propaganda, and that there was a lot of enthusiasm and exuberance, belief in the valour of war. And casualty figures were suppressed. That's all true, but you've really laid out the development in a much more rational way. It's no longer a story of: weren't people crazy back then. And now it's a story of: this is how sane people drove themselves towards madness. And it is important to learn this all at this time now, when propaganda is evolving in new ways we don't yet understand.

Please make the next part about WW2! I know it must be a lot of work to do, you put in incredible detail. Thank you! You're providing many of us English speakers deep insights into German Social History. Even in the 1970s and 80s when I was a child, so much of what we learned about Germany was still hidden by the propaganda. Monty Python's caricatures of of Nazis, Hollywood WW2 movies. There just isn't a lot of comprehension of how it all came to be.

author: @jbkjbk1999
text:
"Cattle for Flanders"

While the Second World War was obviously much more horrible than the first, numerically speaking, I really think there's something about the way the horror of the Great War is expressed that gives it a much bleaker look. Few things in World War 2 capture the poetically crushing sadness of In Flanders Fields or All Quiet on the Western Front.
I think it can be blamed on the complete and utter _absurdity_ of World War 2, as well as (obviously) the way that it's been treatd in culture since. Like, we as people can at least somewhat _comprehend_  what it felt like to be a soldier in the trenches on the western front, not being sure if the grinding monotony was preferable or worse than the periods of chaotic, terrifying yet relatively brief action. We can never truly understand what it was like, of course, but we can at least get an idea of it. I don't think the same can be said for the absurd extent of how utterly horrific the holocaust was. As Stalin (allegedly) said, when one man dies, that's a tragedy, when thousands die, that's a statistic.

This is not to downplay either the holocaust or the first world war. Just an observation on how the two wars seem to be viewd in modern culture, the former generally being viewed as a pointless, monotonous yet intensely traumatising grind, while the latter is viewed as a more frenetic, hollywood-esque war. One is Band of Brothers, the other is _Im Westen nichts Neues_

author: @jacobvardy
text:
I'm kinda curious.  Was the war actually that popular in Germany?  In Australia the media reported the war as universally popular.  But then you read about the laws that heavily punished criticism of the war.  The mass protests against the war (whose organisers were sent to gaol).  The repeated "no" votes in conscription referenda.  The bombing campaign to end the war.  The mass protests to free the bombers...

I read all this and have to wonder if the war was popular.  Or if it was just that it was illegal to print anything critical of the war.  And the newspaper coverage has become the narrative of the war.

author: @tjejojyj
text:
Lenin was so surprised by reports of the SPD vote for war that he first thought it was propaganda.  The Marxists had warned of the danger of war and at the congresses of the second international in Stuttgart (1907), Copenhagen (1910) and Basel (1912) passed anti war resolutions which the SPD supported. 

The SPD leadershipâ€™s betrayal of the resolutions needs to be stated clearly because not all of the SPD covered themselves in shame.  Karl Liebknecht especially deserves mention in this video. Why was he left out? 

Quote 
...
Liebknechtâ€™s protest declares that â€œthis war, which none of the peoples involved desired, was not started for the benefit of the German or of any other people. It is an Imperialist war, a war for capitalist domination of the world markets and for the political domination of the important countries in the interest of industrial and financial capitalism. Arising out of the armament race, it is a preventative war provoked by the German and Austrian war parties in the obscurity of semi-absolutism and of secret diplomacy.

Liebknecht's Protest Against the War Credits

author: @GeoNeilUK
text:
We had similar tales of Germans bayonetting babies.  

And there's also the rumours surrounding the sinking of the Lusitania by a German U-Boat, with the Entente pointing out that this was a civilian liner carrying women and children.  The Central Powers alleged that the Entente were carrying armaments on the Lusitania and it was these armaments that caused the Lusitania to sink, not the torpedos fired into it.  (yes, I'm British, I'm coming from this from a British bias and I wish there had been TV series made of the Great War for the 100th anniversary, there is a very detailed documentary series made by the BBC for the 50th anniversary which is incredibly valuable as it features interviews from those who were at the front in the First War, from both sides I believe)

For Germany, the First World War led directly into the Second World War.

author: @graup1309
text:
One of my favourite quotes from works of fiction set in world war I (from a book called 'My dear I wanted to tell you' , it's quite an interesting book mostly centred around a British hospital near London that did major advances in facial reconstruction surgery) is written down after another big ambush that was supposed to bring victory.
"If no one won that, after all that, that - if neither side won that, then neither side can win. The war won, and goes on winning."
